definition.en: Describes the apparent direction of the sequential path on a P–T diagram, where the x-axis is temperature, and the y-axis is pressure (with positive ordinates above the abscissa). Anticlockwise P–T paths are those in which the thermal maximum (peak temperature) is reached prior to the peak pressure being attained. These P–T paths generally reflect high (geo)thermal gradient and heat flow conditions.

historyNote.none:
a) England, PC and Richardson, SW 1977, The influence of erosion upon the mineral facies of rocks from different metamorphic environments: Journal of the Geological Society,v.134,p.201–213, doi:10.1144/gsjgs.134.2.0201.
b) England, PC and Thompson, AB 1984, Pressure-temperature-time paths of regional metamorphism I. Heat transfer during the evolution of thickened continental crust: Journal of Petrology,v.25,no.4,p.894–928.
c) Harley, SL 1989, The origins of granulites: a metamorphic perspective: Geological Magazine,v.126,no.3,p.215–247, doi:10.1017/S0016756800022330.
d) https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pressure-temperature-time_path

definition.en: Describes the apparent direction of the sequential path on a P–T diagram, where the x-axis is temperature, and the y-axis is pressure (with positive ordinates above the abscissa). Clockwise P–T paths are those in which peak pressure is reached prior to peak temperature being attained. These P–T paths generally reflect burial and subsequent heating under low to intermediate (geo)thermal gradient and heat flow conditions.

historyNote.none:
a) England, PC and Richardson, SW 1977, The influence of erosion upon the mineral facies of rocks from different metamorphic environments: Journal of the Geological Society,v.134,p.201–213, doi:10.1144/gsjgs.134.2.0201.

c) Harley, SL 1989, The origins of granulites: a metamorphic perspective: Geological Magazine,v.126,no.3,p.215–247, doi:10.1017/S0016756800022330.
d) https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pressure-temperature-time_path

definition.en: Metamorphic conditions under which the pressure (P) remains constant over a period of time (t) during a metamorphic event.

historyNote.none:
a) England, PC and Richardson, SW 1977, The influence of erosion upon the mineral facies of rocks from different metamorphic environments: Journal of the Geological Society,v.134,p.201–213, doi:10.1144/gsjgs.134.2.0201.
b) England, PC and Thompson, AB 1984, Pressure-temperature-time paths of regional metamorphism I. Heat transfer during the evolution of thickened continental crust: Journal of Petrology,v.25,no.4,p.894–928.
c) Harley, SL 1989, The origins of granulites: a metamorphic perspective: Geological Magazine,v.126,no.3,p.215–247, doi:10.1017/S0016756800022330.
d) https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Isobaric_process

definition.en: Metamorphic conditions under which the pressure (P) remains constant as temperature decreases (i.e. cooling) over a period of time (t).

historyNote.none:
a) England, PC and Richardson, SW 1977, The influence of erosion upon the mineral facies of rocks from different metamorphic environments: Journal of the Geological Society,v.134,p.201–213, doi:10.1144/gsjgs.134.2.0201.
b) England, PC and Thompson, AB 1984, Pressure-temperature-time paths of regional metamorphism I. Heat transfer during the evolution of thickened continental crust: Journal of Petrology,v.25,no.4,p.894–928.
c) Harley, SL 1989, The origins of granulites: a metamorphic perspective: Geological Magazine,v.126,no.3,p.215–247, doi:10.1017/S0016756800022330.

definition.en: Metamorphic conditions under which the pressure (P) remains constant as temperature increases (i.e. heating) over a period of time (t).

historyNote.none:
a) England, PC and Richardson, SW 1977, The influence of erosion upon the mineral facies of rocks from different metamorphic environments: Journal of the Geological Society,v.134,p.201–213, doi:10.1144/gsjgs.134.2.0201.

c) Harley, SL 1989, The origins of granulites: a metamorphic perspective: Geological Magazine,v.126,no.3,p.215–247, doi:10.1017/S0016756800022330.

definition.en: Metamorphic conditions under which the temperature (T) remains constant over a period of time (t), during a metamorphic event.

historyNote.none:
a) England, PC and Richardson, SW 1977, The influence of erosion upon the mineral facies of rocks from different metamorphic environments: Journal of the Geological Society,v.134,p.201–213, doi:10.1144/gsjgs.134.2.0201.

definition.en: Metamorphic conditions under which the temperature (T) remains constant while the pressure decreases over a period of time (t).

definition.en: Metamorphic conditions under which the temperature (T) remains constant while pressure increases over a period of time (t).

definition.en: The pressure(P)–temperature(T)–time(t) path for a specific metamorphic event is unknown.
